I'd consider a data class with named fields:
data class AvailableSpace(val hasEnoughSpace: Boolean, val availableSpace: Long)
or somehting similar (this is Kotlin, btw).
Pair is pretty useful concept in general, but the first and second field names are less than helpful when reading. I guess this is why Java did not ship Pair at all, argumenting that one should just create a well-named type instead.
If you believe that we should use Pair anyway, please consider using the class available in Kotlin stdlib instead of Android platform API, which gives us headaches during testing.
What happens on older Android versions?

The "Free up space" button will simply not appear, because this function is unavailable before Jelly Bean.
And, I take this opportunity to ask you why you stay on a minimal level of compilation on Android 4.1 (API level 16), it's a system that is 8 years old today.
Without getting ahead of myself, I would say that the application is too complex today to run successfully (all the features) on Jelly Bean, are you planning to change the  minSdkVersion over time?

are you planning to change the minSdkVersion over time?

Yes, we do. The rule (introduced with the latest feature release): #150 --> check if oldest Android version is EOL by Google and user usage <= 0.5% and drop it if so
